Description

A fierce warrior who can enter a battle rage

Hit Die: d12
Primary Ability: &Reference[str]{Strength}
Saves: &Reference[str]{Strength} & Constitution 

Class Features

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.wowaaUeP7mhfQtXe]{Equipment}

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a greataxe or (b) any martial melee weapon
  • (a) two handaxes or (b) any simple weapon
  • An explorer’s pack and four javelins

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.OQDs9b0HK20532Wq]{Rage}

In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on &Reference[str]{Strength} checks and &Reference[str]{Strength} saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using &Reference[str]{Strength}, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to &Reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning}, &Reference[piercing]{piercing}, and &Reference[slashing]{slashing} damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.vpAPS3sTQIJSYeT1]{Unarmored Defense}

While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your &Reference[dex]{Dexterity} modifier + your &Reference[con]{Constitution} modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.APLX5GH6uSzW57yP]{Reckless Attack}

Starting at 2nd level, you can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using &Reference[str]{Strength} during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.pWx1bk3qVdSkeaoa]{Danger Sense}

At 2nd level, you gain an uncanny sense of when things nearby aren’t as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge away from danger.

You have advantage on &Reference[dex]{Dexterity} saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can’t be &Reference[blinded]{blinded}, &Reference[deafened]{deafened}, or &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated}.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.G14PrPlbm3w2Ccig]{Primal Path}

At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the &Reference[nat]{nature} of your rage. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.blIKT5aTQk8M0cMc]{Ability Score Improvement}

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.5h3MeRh09TTVGnys]{Extra Attack}

Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.JLcX1lRglYoXzm0U]{Fast Movement}

Starting at 5th level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren’t wearing heavy armor.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.pi1fkh2CcZXv3DAN]{Feral Instinct}

By 7th level, your instincts are so honed that you have advantage on initiative rolls.

Additionally, if you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren’t &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated}, you can act normally on your first turn, but only if you enter your rage before doing anything else on that turn.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.GgrRfx9sZ2KkTluq]{Brutal Critical}

Beginning at 9th level, you can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to two additional dice at 13th level and three additional dice at 17th level.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.muqfkVhoQdu0qets]{Relentless Rage}

Starting at 11th level, your rage can keep you fighting despite grievous wounds. If you drop to 0 hit points while you’re raging and don’t die outright, you can make a [[/save con 10 format=long]]. If you succeed, you drop to 1 hit point instead.

Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a short or long rest, the DC resets to 10.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.EXU7qsv6mPouhK1r]{Persistent Rage}

Beginning at 15th level, your rage is so fierce that it ends early only if you fall &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} or if you choose to end it.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.b9KNXfmgvZR7WGqI]{Indomitable Might}

Beginning at 18th level, if your total for a &Reference[str]{Strength} check is less than your &Reference[str]{Strength} score, you can use that score in place of the total.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.HKM40KyQC1rlp2uN]{Primal Champion}

At 20th level, you embody the power of the wilds. Your &Reference[str]{Strength} and &Reference[con]{Constitution} scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

Starting Equipment

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a greataxe or (b) any martial melee weapon
  • (a) two handaxes or (b) any simple weapon
  • An explorer’s pack and four javelins

Description

A fierce warrior who can enter a battle rage

Hit Die: d12
Primary Ability: &Reference[str]{Strength}
Saves: &Reference[str]{Strength} & Constitution 

Class Features

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.0QxshyX3Pl8xnXgp]{Restriction: Dwarves Only}

Only dwarves can follow the Path of the Battlerager. The battlerager fills a particular niche in dwarven society and culture.

Your DM can lift this restriction to better suit the campaign. The restriction exists for the Forgotten Realms. It might not apply to your DM’s setting or your DM’s version of the Realms.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.ozw2SDAFgQ2ztOjb]{Battlerager Armor}

When you choose this path at 3rd level, you gain the ability to use spiked armor (see the “Spiked Armor” sidebar) as a weapon.

While you are wearing spiked armor and are raging, you can use a bonus action to make one melee weapon attack with your armor spikes against a target within 5 feet of you. If the attack hits, the spikes deal 1d4 &Reference[piercing]{piercing} damage. You use your &Reference[str]{Strength} modifier for the attack and damage rolls.

Additionally, when you use the Attack action to grapple a creature, the target takes 3 &Reference[piercing]{piercing} damage if your grapple check succeeds.

SPIKED ARMOR

Spiked armor is a rare type of medium armor made by dwarves. It consists of a leather coat and leggings covered with spikes that are usually made of metal.
Cost: 75 gp
AC: 14 + &Reference[dex]{Dexterity} modifier (max 2)
Stealth: Disadvantage 
Weight: 45 lb.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.AT06uckTvevEPVPQ]{Reckless Abandon}

Beginning at 6th level, when you use Reckless Attack while raging, you also gain temporary hit points equal to your &Reference[con]{Constitution} modifier (minimum of 1). They vanish if any of them are left when your rage ends.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.dOnFBYEXjuwI5Gmq]{Battlerager Charge}

Beginning at 10th level, you can take the Dash action as a bonus action while you are raging.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.x7PXER6JjKAaQu7v]{Spiked Retribution}

Starting at 14th level, when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the attacker takes 3 &Reference[piercing]{piercing} damage if you are raging, aren’t &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated}, and are wearing spiked armor.

Bold and hardy, dwarves are known as skilled warriors, miners, and workers of stone and metal.

Racial Traits
+2 &Reference[con]{Constitution}, &Reference[darkvision]{Darkvision}, Dwarven Resilience, Dwarven Combat Training, Stonecunning

As a mountain dwarf, you’re strong and hardy, accustomed to a difficult life in rugged terrain. You’re probably on the tall side (for a dwarf), and tend toward lighter coloration. The shield dwarves of northern Faerûn, as well as the ruling Hylar clan and the noble Daewar clan of Dragonlance, are mountain dwarves.

&Reference[darkvision]{Darkvision}

Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.0CBTlkt2KgIIgEpz]{Dwarven Resilience}

You have advantage on saving throws against &Reference[poison]{poison}, and you have resistance against &Reference[poison]{poison} damage (explained in the “Combat” section).

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.4LLEPuJUlTEjs34p]{Dwarven Combat Training}

You have proficiency with the battleaxe, handaxe, light hammer, and warhammer.

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.n3GyuraNdNR3opNO]{Tool Proficiency}

You gain proficiency with the artisan’s tools of your choice: smith’s tools, brewer’s supplies, or mason’s tools.

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.XIilIfZhsyciaNsI]{Stonecunning}

Whenever you make an &Reference[int]{Intelligence} (&Reference[his]{History}) check related to the origin of stonework, you are considered proficient in the &Reference[his]{History} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

Ability Score Increase

Your &Reference[con]{Constitution} score increases by 2.

Languages

You can speak, read, and write Common and Dwarvish. Dwarvish is full of hard consonants and guttural sounds, and those characteristics spill over into whatever other language a dwarf might speak.

Age

Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they’re considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

Size

Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

Speed

Your base walking speed is 25 feet. Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

Ability Score Increase

Your &Reference[str]{Strength} score increases by 2.

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.lXCOkAExAmsXAlCD]{Dwarven Armor Training}

You have proficiency with light and medium armor.

You have advantage on saves against &Reference[poison]{poison} and resistance against &Reference[poison]{poison} damage.
More Details

Background: Athlete

You strive to perfect yourself physically and in execution of everything you do. The thrill of competition lights &Reference[fire]{fire} in your blood, and the roar of the crowd drives you forward. Tales of your exploits precede you and might open doors or loosen tongues.

Whether in one of the poleis, between them, or among the nonhuman peoples of Theros, physical contests and those who pursue them command respect bordering on reverence. Athletes arise from all walks of life and all cultures and quite often cross paths with one another.

Skill Proficiencies: &Reference[acr]{Acrobatics}, &Reference[ath]{Athletics}

Tool Proficiencies: Vehicles (land)

Languages: One of your choice

Equipment: A bronze discus or leather ball, a lucky charm or past trophy, a set of traveler’s clothes, and a pouch containing 10 gp

Favored Event

While many athletes practice various games and events, most excel at a single form of competition. Roll or choose from the options in the Favored Event table to determine the athletic event in which you excel.

Favored Event
d8 Favored Event
1 Marathon
2 Long-distance running
3 Wrestling
4 Boxing
5 Chariot or horse race
6 Pankration (mixed unarmed combat)
7 Hoplite race (racing in full armor with a unit)
8 Pentathlon (running, long jump, discus, javelin, wrestling)
@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.roll-tables.RollTable.yZVOCjerPTApbna4]{Open RollTable Background: Athlete: Favored Event}
Feature: Echoes of Victory

You have attracted admiration among spectators, fellow athletes, and trainers in the region that hosted your past athletic victories. When visiting any settlement within 100 miles of where you grew up, there is a 50 percent chance you can find someone there who admires you and is willing to provide information or temporary shelter.

Between adventures, you might compete in athletic events sufficient enough to maintain a comfortable lifestyle, as per the “Practicing a Profession” downtime activity in chapter 8 of the Player’s Handbook.

You make a melee attack that involves using your body to deal one of the following effects: Damage: You make an attack roll against the creature, and on a hit, you deal [[1+ @abilities.str.mod]] &Reference[bludgeoning]{Bludgeoning} damage. Grapple: The target must succeed on a DC [[8 + @abilities.str.mod + @prof]] Str./Dex. (it chooses which) saving throw or it has the &Reference[grappled]{Grappled} condition. Shove: The target must succeed on a DC [[8 + @abilities.str.mod + @prof]] Str./Dex. (it chooses which) saving throw or you can either push it 5 ft. away or cause it to have the &Reference[prone]{Prone} condition.
More Details

Instead of using a weapon to make a melee attack, you can use a punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow. In game terms, this is an Unarmed Strike—a melee attack that involves you using your body to damage, grapple, or shove a target within 5 feet of you.

Whenever you use your Unarmed Strike, choose one of the following options for its effect.

Damage. You make an attack roll against the target. Your bonus to the roll equals your &Reference[str]{Strength} modifier plus your Proficiency Bonus. On a hit, the target takes &Reference[bludgeoning]{Bludgeoning} damage equal to 1 plus your &Reference[str]{Strength} modifier.

Grapple. The target must succeed on a &Reference[str]{Strength} or &Reference[dex]{Dexterity} saving throw (it chooses which), or it has the &Reference[grappled]{Grappled} condition. The DC for the saving throw and any escape attempts equals 8 plus your &Reference[str]{Strength} modifier and Proficiency Bonus. This grapple is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you and if you have a hand free to grab it.

Shove. The target must succeed on a &Reference[str]{Strength} or &Reference[dex]{Dexterity} saving throw (it chooses which), or you either push it 5 feet away or cause it to have the &Reference[prone]{Prone} condition. The DC for the saving throw equals 8 plus your &Reference[str]{Strength} modifier and Proficiency Bonus. This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you.

As a bonus action enter a rage for up to 1 minute (10 rounds). You gain advantage on STR checks and saving throws (not attacks), [[/roll @scale.barbarian.rage]] melee damage with STR weapons, resistance to &Reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning}, &Reference[piercing]{piercing}, &Reference[slashing]{slashing} damage. You can't cast or concentrate on spells while raging. Your rage ends early if you are knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage as a bonus action.
More Details

In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.
